Gender and zolpidem side effects
We are used to referencing guidance about dose adjustments based on age, weight, genetics or organ function but less so related to gender. When I reviewed LexiComp for zolpidem and considered this case for Roseanne Barr, I wondered: What causes the need to have such large differences in dosage between men and women? Are women more susceptible to side effects?
My research showed that the USDA had to revise dosing guidelines for zolpidem after it found that women were had more day-after effects related to slower clearance (Chu, 2014). I wondered if body composition differences, such as body mass and percentage body fat could be the main factors in this gender difference. I recall how body fat and body water influence the volume of distribution of a drug and therefore affect the clearance time. These issues are certainly important factors, but I found that there is also an interesting linkage between CYP metabolism and testosterone. Specifically, researchers found that testosterone may enhance CYP3A4 metabolism. This finding sheds light on men’s increasing sensitivity to zolpidem with age as well as women’s increased sensitivity across the lifespan (Olubodun, 2003).
Based on reported side effects, it appears to me that Roseanne Barr has reason to argue that her intake of zolpidem contributed to her making socially inappropriate comments. LexiComp’s listing of side effects, which include behavior change, amnesia, abnormal thinking, a decreased inhibition, certainly point to how this drug may have influenced her actions. Nonetheless, I disagree that she is not liable for her actions. We hold individuals responsible for what they have done while under the influence of alcohol and other drugs, all the while agreeing that those substances contributed to the events at hand.
Reference:

Ambien Defense
The first thing that came to mind when I read about Roseanne Barr’s tweet was that drunks and kids always say what they are thinking with no regards to anyone’s feelings or rational. We joke about it as adults and call it “liquid courage,” and Ambien has the same type of effect. It is considered a hypnotic and has the same effect as a benzodiazepine (LexiComp, 2018). In LexiComp (2018) one of the concerns related to the use of Ambien is abnormal thinking, behavioral changes, decreased inhibition, and bizarre behavior. However, it also stated that these changes may occur unpredictably and may indicate previously unrecognized psychiatric disorders and should be evaluated (Hauser, 2018). Dr. W. Christopher Winter of Charlottesville Neurology and Sleep Medicine believes Ambien “reveals the kinds of thoughts you are having which you are actively suppressing; Ambien allows those kinds of thoughts to be expressed” (Hauser, 2018).
Ambien has a half-life of 2.5 hours, and at 11.25 hours the drug will be 95% eliminated from the body (LexiComp, 2018). Barr made her racist comments at 2:00 in the morning, making the argument that she was tweeting while under the influence of the drug. The Ambien defense could have been used had she not had a history of having some pretty irrational thoughts and tweeting them. Barr promoted Pizzagate, tweeted that 9/11 was an inside job, and she once called Israel a “Nazi state” in 2009 (Coaston, 2018). Barr also helped to promote a Holocaust-denying musician in 2013, in the same year she also attacked Susan Rice, another Obama official, calling her “a man with big swinging ape balls” (Coaston, 2018). She can’t use Ambien defense when she’s known to have bizarre tweets.
With its half-life, Ambien, can have lingering mental effects the morning after use, and not just drowsiness. The verbal memory may slip along with mental focus, causing the individual to have a hard time concentrating (Carey, 2018). Which did not seem to be the case for Barr because she kept on tweeting and even having a tweeter feud with Chelsea Clinton. I agree with Dr. Winter that these types of drugs have a way of bringing our subconscious thoughts, whether good or bad, of coming out.

Roseanne Bar Ambien tweet
The first question that came to mind as I read the article on Roseanne Barr’s Ambien tweet was, what are the side effects of Zolpidem (Ambien)?  Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine sedative-hypnotic used in the short-term management of insomnia and according to Lexicomp 2018, it specifically helps with decreasing the time it takes one to fall asleep and helps the patient stay asleep increasing total sleep time.  Zolpidem conventional tablets are rapidly absorbed in the gastrointestinal (GI) system following oral administration and have a bioavailability of 70 percent and a half-life of 2-3 hours (Whalen, K., 2015, p. 129).  The peak concentration is approximately 1.6 hours. Zolpidem undergoes first pass and is metabolized and excreted through the hepatic system via CYP450 thus, drugs that inhibit CYP3A4 isoenzyme can prolong the half-life of the drug (Lexi-Comp 2018).  Regarding Roseanne Barr, I do not know her age, what she ate prior to taking the drug, and I do not know if she drank alcohol that night.  I do not have a medical history specifically liver disease all which could influence the side effects.
In the Roseanne Barr article, On May 29, 2018, she tweeted at 02:45hrs something to the effect that the Muslim brotherhood and the planet of the apes equal Valerie Jared.  According to the article, this is the reason Roseanne Barr lost her television show. The most common side effects are headaches, dizziness, anxiety, lethargy, and GI problems such as diarrhea.  Several drug sites mention special populations regarding Zolpidem such women and the elderly.  According to Lexicomp, women and the elderly tend to have higher peak concentrations and AUC 45 percent to 75 percent higher than men with the same dose.  In 2013, the FDA recommended decreasing the maximum dose for the elderly and women.  The complex behavioral side effects of Ambien have decreased inhibition, extroversion, driving a vehicle, cooking and eating, having sex, making phone calls while not fully awake and, at times, having lost all memory of the events.
In a statement by Sonofi US, the makers of Zolpidem, they argued that even though drugs have side effects, racism is not one of them.  I tend to agree with that statement and I feel that there is no drug that can change the way you think. The fact that the drug has been known on rare occasion to cause disinhibition and extroversion I cannot dispute Rosanne Barr’s assertions that the drug led her to write the now infamous tweet, as she could have been uninhibited by the drug's effect.  It may have lessened her inhibition about writing what she thought as a comedian, however, it would not influence her actual thoughts.

Ambien and Barr
After making her racist comments, Roseanne Barr said that she took Ambien and “I went 2 far & do not want it defended” (Hauser, 2018). My question after reading this article was did the makers of Ambien, Sanofi U.S., really address Roseanne’s claims or were they just jumping on the bandwagon and kicking Ms. Barr while she was down?
One of the known side-effects of Ambien is “decreased inhibition” (Zolpidem, 2018). This alone cannot account for the racist behaviors that Ms. Barr displayed.  However, in an article by Smith and Mendoza-Denton (2016) titled, “How to Stop the Racist in You,” the authors explain that “the new science of implicit bias suggests that the problem is not only with bad apples. Instead, prejudice is a conflict that plays out within each and every one of us” (Smith & Mendoza-Denton, 2016). They further explain, “We all carry prejudices within ourselves—and we all have the tools to keep them in check” (Smith & Mendoza-Denton, 2016). I would argue that one of those tools is inhibition. Roseanne Bar did have implicit biases that she may not have acted on if she had that inhibition. When I read her twitter statement, I do not see it as a defense, in fact, she says, “I went 2 far & do not want it defended” (Hauser, 2018). I see this is a recognition that she became racist and cannot excuse her behavior. It also is a recognition that her behavior is affected by Ambien. People have made similar recognitions in the past with recreational drugs like alcohol. For example, it is well known that some people are more likely to be verbally or physically abusive when they drink alcohol, and it is important that people recognize how their behavior can be negatively affected by a drug.
Instead of giving a short statement about how their drug does not cause racism, I think it would have been much more helpful if Sanofi U.S. had instead discussed how Ambien can decrease inhibitions and may allow implicit biases to be expressed more frequently rather than focus on their drug not getting bad press.

"The Ambien Defense"
In the New York Times article by Christine Hauser (2018) and in a follow up article by Benedict Carey (2018), it was noted that while Ambien (zolpidem) has a number of adverse effects that can impair cognition and memory, it would not in-fact cause one to suddenly make racists remarks when one did not have previously held racist thoughts, perceptions, or beliefs. Zolpidem, a hypnotic/sedative drug, however, does have listed as adverse effects abnormal thinking and behavior changes (Zolpidem - Lexi-Drugs, 2018). Other adverse effects, while having a risk of 1% or less than 1%, include disinhibition, cognitive dysfunction, and abnormal thinking (Zolpidem - Lexi-Drugs, 2018). Consequently, the question that comes to my mind is, could someone with good intentions and consciously held beliefs of racial equality, then express subconscious beliefs while on zolpidem? While I do not condone Roseann Barr’s comments and think she must be held responsible for her actions, the question still remains could zolpidem alter one’s cognitive functioning and disinhibition to a point that they would do something as egregious as Ms. Barr?
While the New York Times articles would argue against the “Ambien defense”, I think one should take a closer look at the pharmacokinetics of zolpidem in order to understand how such a grievous offense could have occurred. Zolpidem’s mechanism of action is primarily through the inhibition of neural action potential causing a decrease in neural excitability thus inducing sedative-like effects (Zolpidem - Lexi-Drugs, 2018). While the volume of distribution is low which would lead one to believe it would be excreted relatively quickly, it is interesting to note that the AUC is significantly increased in women compared to men due to decreased clearance rates in women. While this does not explain Ms. Barr’s racist remarks, it does elucidate the fact that the drug likely stayed in her system longer thus giving more time for adverse effects such as disinhibition to occur and wreak havoc throughout social media.
When considering the effects of zolpidem and culpability, the law article by Daley, McNiel, and Binder (2011) discusses many pertinent cases in which people blamed zolpidem on various criminal activities. However, the summary of this article notes that it is important to consider the history of the plaintiff in regards to similar activity or premeditation. In the case of Roseann Barr, two things should be considered: this was not her first outburst on social media and as the old adage goes “out of the heart the mouth speaks”. While she may be able to get away with blaming zolpidem on her disinhibition, if she had not had these thoughts before she likely would not have expressed them while cognitively impaired.

I, too, like Mead's definition of culture; so it is a good starting point. I am much more partial to the definition suggested by Hall and adopted in our text (page 1) - Culture is communication and communication is culture.
We have to be careful not to make our definitions of culture ahistorical, divorced from space and time. As Jaques Derrida describes in Of Grammatology, we understand a concept by drawing a line through it, by its negation. For example, we are compelled to use terms like "American culture" - but we have to be precise in the limitations of such a term; the culture of an Inuit family in Alaska is quite different from that of a Scandinavian-origin family of Catholics in North Dakota, though both may watch the same college football games and root for similar teams. There are shared commonalities, and great differences.
In the foreword to Madness and Civilization Michel Foucault writes that if a thing does not communicate, it dies. The same is true of all consciousness and cultures. Our text captures the foundational and mediating aspect of culture in the statement that culture is negotiated and mediated through a communication processes.

In this regard, I have to say I heartily disagree with the ideas that the "west" has an individualistic culture and other countries,such as in Asia, have a more group-oriented culture. What is problematic in this typification - first,explore the concept "western": it is clearly not geographical: it breaks down when we think of the geographical edges of this concept. Is the eastern extremity in Istanbul,Turkey? Is Russia "western"? Where in Siberia does the "west" end? Novosibirsk? How about historically? When did the "west" come into existence? This origin is often co-located with "Greek" civilization. The Greeks were located all around the Mediterranean and many discoveries we think of as "Greek" were from parts influenced greatly by Turkey (in turn influenced greatly by countries father east) and African thinking; and came from Greek city-states located in Africa and Asia. Or, consider some "western" histories pre-dating Christianity - are the Vikings western? The Druids? It appears that commonly, in strategic terms, we think of "western" as the Anglo-American led alliance that includes some European states, but this alliance now includes many former "eastern" states. I am trying to make the point that when we try to pin the concept "western" down geographically, historically (what years?), it breaks down. The same holds true for "eastern" - take India for instance where I was born and where I lived till twenty-seven: I worked for a summer in a rain forest with indigenous forest dwellers who lived a somewhat subsistence life-style with few market interactions, and much fishing, hunting, and slash-and-burn agriculture; and another summer at the National Aeronautical Laboratories with scientists doing supersonic re-entry research using one of the world's largest supersonic wind tunnels. E-Learning is a type of learning done virtually rather than face to face instruction. This type of learning requires a digital device and Internet connection in order to have access to the course. E-Learning can be convenient to the learner because it allows them to manage the course around their schedule. Great question! I was thinking towards a question like this, basically how could E-Learning accommodate each learner and their cultural background. So to answer your question, yes I think developing it to where it would match each user's perception would promote acceptance of E-Learning in various cultures.
As we have learned from the assigned reading, Globalized E-Learning Cultural Challenges, the design of the course is just as important as the actual content."The purpose is to build mutual accommodation and respect for the culture of others in order to reach academic success." (Edmundson, 2007, pg.10) This not only depends on the language being used within the course, but also how the course is designed for the learner. This is quite an interesting discussion on what culture means to each of us and the ways in which it influences our actions, beliefs, ideals, etc.. For the most part, I agree with Maddie Williams's definition of culture in that we are all products of our environment and that we are sculpted individually by the circumstances and experiences of our lives. Indeed, most of us are predefined (both internally and externally) by the cultures in which we were brought up. As an American, I am well-aware of the ways in which values/beliefs such as self-sufficiency, individualism, and 'manifest destiny' have influenced my development and worldview. While I strive to be aware of my cultural biases and control for them, upon introspection I often find that they are still highly prevalent in the way in which I interact with the world around me. 
Additionally, the definition (and reflections) on culture from many of you mirrors my own in that it suggests the development (and prevalence of) wisdom within our respective communities. While we all have unique upbringings, belief structures, and identities, a common thread that I have noticed is that these values and beliefs about culture can often be similarly applied to those who we deem to be "wise" within our communities. We discuss aspects of knowledge, community-mindedness, and norm-expression, which are all discussed in our readings this week regarding wisdom, 'wise communities,' and the WISCOM framework. To me, culture and wisdom go hand-in-hand. Culture, in a general framework, sets the standard for who we are, strive to be, and what is expected of us within various social groups and roles. As such, someone who encompasses these beliefs, ideals, etc., is seen as 'wise' due to their abilities to navigate and communicate within these roles/norms. I am curious, therefore, about the universiality of wisdom across communities; as we saw in Gunawardena, Frechette, & Layne (2019), wisdom is a concept that is recognized across cultures and communities throughout the world (with varying definitions and expectations) and while there is a common thread across these definitions, I cannot help but assume that someone who is deemed 'wise' in one culture may not be similarly seen in another. In this way, wisdom, like culture, is contextually-dependent.
In terms of e-Learning, I would agree that it is a form of education that occurs within the digital/online environment (as many of you have stated). Simply put, it is distance education supported by a digital communication medium. For me, I do not see the distinction between "learning" and "e-Learning" as relevant anymore considering the speeds at which we can interact online these days; the idea of e-Learning (to me) suggests asynchronous and piecemeal learning within an online framework which, while relevant a decade ago, is not representative of the capabilities of today. 
To elaborate, connectivity today allows us to communicate in real-time across the world. This goes far beyond simply chatting or a Skype call in that we can now work collaboratively on large, data-intensive processes regardless of geographic distance. A scientist in China can control a robot on the US East Coast with little-to-no lag time between command and execution; when it comes to education, this means that we can learn together as a class with minimal technical problems and complete even the most robust assignments in real-time (controlling for any logistical issues of course). 
There is the issue (opportunity) of culture within the e-Learning environment that we must discuss. While we have discussed (and attempted to minimize) the opportunities of e-Learning within the contemporary online environment, this has simply allowed us to better examine/appreciate the differences in personal culture/learning preferences of learners. Without the limitations of 'classic' e-Learning, we are now able to experience online learning on the same terms as learning in the classroom wherein we can engage with individuals as more than a name on the screen in some theoretical place we have never seen or (perhaps) ever heard of. 
On a final note, I agree with Rachel Brown that e-Learning strikes me as a "buzzword" from a time past when organizations learned the potential of decentralized and digitally-driven education in the workplace. As suggested above, the term "e-Learning" feels foreign and clunky as I don't feel that it adequately captures the essence of online/distance learning as an equal to traditional classroom learning. Perhaps this is from my upbringing which looked upon online education with derision as an inferior form of education to in-person learning.

For this exercise, I wanted to see what my ideas about culture and eLearning were without having read any of the assigned readings in order to see how my conceptions of them changed within the new context of this class. It has been interesting to watch how my definitions become more complex as my understanding of the studies around these two topics changes.
Culture: Original definition
A combination of practices, traditions and behavioral norms adhered to by a group of people that consciously or unconsciously tie them to / identify them as a part of a defined group.
Culture: Updated Understanding
What struck me most was Vigotsky's conceptualization of "development as the transformation of socially shared activities into internalized processes." In this way, culture is taught in an interphyscological way (between people), and also intraphsychologically (within ourselves as individuals). Although this was part of the cultural-historical perspective on learning section (Gunawardena 2019, page 18), it's interesting to consider how much of culture is tacit (unspoken, but agreed upon by engaging within that culture) and how much of it is explicit (something you knowingly and willfully engage in).The WisCom framework attempts to incorporate this understanding by including an emphasis on the influence of culture and context within learning (Gunawardena 2019, page 21), and what what I was attempting to capture by noting that we are consciously or unconsciously tied to it. It seems the more we are aware of our own cultural underpinnings, the more conscious and inclusive we can be of others'.
I especially appreciated the Zulu maxim "a person is a person through other persons" (Gunawardena 2019, page 45).  Kate Charles, I wonder if this is something similar to what you meant when you said that although your values stay the same, the culture that you interact with is different at work than it is in church. I wonder if this transformation, or perhaps "code-switching" (a term that was once meant to describe switching from one language to another based on the setting in linguistics, but has become commonly understood to mean switching your language, dialect, accent, references or cultural norms to fit a specific cultural setting) is something that we all engage in, however subtly, as our culture and values are an inherent part of our personhood, but that the expression of that culture varies based on our environment.
This only becomes more complex as we discuss Goodfellow & Hewling's writing on high and low context settings, which can be used to contextualize interactions and interpret someone's meaning (Goodfellow & Hewling 2005, page 357). Mallory Fetterolf, I wonder if this is also part of what you were referencing when you mentioned intersectional nature of culture.
eLearning: Original Definition
Similar to Annie Mederios, I originally considered eLearning to simply be a curriculum or program of study delivered through methods that are supplied solely online or via the Internet.  
eLearning: Updated Understanding
This becomes ever more complex when you consider that culture, context and social interaction shape learning, including via language, signs and systems (Gunawardena 2019, page 17). What struck me the most is how varied eLearning can be, and how Distance Education and eLearning are not interchangeable. It seems to me that eLearning, in its most basic form, is defined in my original definition, but that it has many components. It seemed that some people thought that eLearning and Distance Ed were the same thing, but I read the case studies between by Goodfellow & Hewling to show just how different they are, where Distance Education followed a more prescribed form of learning, with provided printed materials, set meeting times etc., but the eLearning emphasizes the leveraging of the Internet to ensure that the learning has a very flexible and accommodating learning environment, tailored to their learning preferences. Rachel Brown, I specifically appreciated your thought on this.
I know that we are working on a consensus of what these two definitions should be, and I hope I haven't simply added to the noise here! Thank you all for sharing your thoughts!

As Rachel Brown expressed, I to share the idea that eLearning is the current term or concept for distance education.  eLearning is unique as it enables numerous communities to collaborate in real-time while utilizing a variety of formats to maximize audience comprehension and promote dynamic teaching styles. How culture and eLearning are related
The internet and its ability to connect people around the world and share knowledge marks a unique period in human existence.  The opening of our text powerfully sets the stage with respect to how culture and eLearning are related.  Time and space no longer limit how we interact with one another.  Technologies, particularly the Internet, have connected humanity across countries and cultures with profound implications on how we think, communicate and learn (Gunawardena, Frechette, Layne 2019).  As Caroline Sanchez suggested, I agree, we do develop our own unique cultures within online communities as we notice in the OILS course.  We actively develop more awareness of our classmates’ communication styles while we exercise sensitivity to expand our knowledge of understanding of the group dynamic and the instructional content.
Maddie Williams’s Question: 
Would developing eLearning and teaching models which match to the user's perception promote acceptance to eLearning in different cultures?"
I believe eLearning can gain acceptance in different cultures if Instructional Designer and or Instructor/Content Expert exercise cultural sensitivity in design and reflection of the quality of audience/instructor interaction.  Sustaining objectivity is critical as stagnation can limit conceptual designs for unique culturally diverse audiences and functions.  Instruction that promotes learning across cultures seeks to accommodate diverse perspectives and preferences by following the principles of universal design for learning (UDL) rather than anticipate individual learner differences upfront.  These principles emphasize flexibility and learner choice. (Barajas & Higbee, 2003).  As we design with rearguard to our audience’s perception, review, evaluate, revise and remain engages as learners of design concepts while exercising cultural sensitivity, eLearning can and will gain acceptance.
